page.title: 05SHEEP FARMING
page.content: Four farms in the area have sheep on them. The usual yearly cycle for sheep farming is: August - November the rams are put to the ewes, the gestation period is 147 days. December - February the main flock of ewes, lamb. These lambs are left with their mothers indoors for quick fattening to be sold in about 12 weeks when reaching 36kg. In April the young ewes lamb; their lambs are de-tailed and castrated and mainly kept until next year to be sold as whethers. May - June the sheep are sheared and the fleeces sold. July - October the sheep must be dipped, by law, to guard against 'sheep scab'. The main breeds used in this area are Cluns, Suffolks, Texels and crosses of these.
